data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: fit N Christmas tree toys (N=1-200) into smallest square bounding box. Score = sum of (side^2 / N) for all N. Lower is better. Target: beat 68.931058.
Key tool: bbox3 binary optimizer - runs with parameters -n (iterations) and -r (restarts). Used by top kernels. Example: ./bbox3 -n 2000 -r 96

fix_direction function: Optimizes rotation of entire configuration to minimize bounding box. Uses scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar to find optimal rotation angle (0-90 degrees). Critical post-processing step.

Santa Claude kernel uses C++ tree_packer with OpenMP parallelization. Features: simulated annealing, local search, squeeze/compaction, swap moves, multi-start optimization. Also uses backward_propagation to improve smaller N configs from larger ones.
Overlap repair strategy: If optimization creates overlaps, replace those N configurations with known-good baseline configurations from a donor file.

Key optimization techniques for 2D packing: 1) Simulated annealing with temperature scheduling, 2) Local search with multi-directional moves, 3) Squeeze/compaction towards center, 4) Rotation optimization (fix_direction), 5) Backward propagation (improve smaller N from larger N configs), 6) Swap moves between trees

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D polygon packing optimization to minimize bounding box?
web_research.finding:
2‑D polygon packing – the task of arranging a set of possibly irregular polygons inside the smallest possible axis‑aligned rectangle (the bounding box) without overlap – is a classic NP‑hard combinatorial optimisation problem that appears in sheet‑metal cutting, textile layout, texture‑atlas generation and many other manufacturing and graphics pipelines.  Because an exact solution is computationally prohibitive for realistic instance sizes, research has produced a spectrum of approaches ranging from exact integer‑programming formulations to fast approximation and learning‑based heuristics.

The most widely used exact and geometric methods are the **envelope‑polygon**, **pixel**, **no‑fit‑polygon (NFP)** and **mixed‑integer programming (MIP)** techniques, which model the spatial relationships of the pieces and allow a solver to explore feasible placements ([frontiersin.org](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/mechanical-engineering/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)).
